content: I don’t think any of this needs to be so complicated, so I can only figure that College Football enjoys people having needless confusion and circular debates (because it produces suspense and interest, I guess). It seems pretty straightforward that a team’s “resume” is a combination of their record, how tough their schedule was, and whether or not they won their conference. “Game control” or “when did the win happen” or “but their QB was limping for the second half of that one game” are all arguments that have no place in deciding the outcomes of any other respected sport that I can think of, and we don’t need it here. I made a simple algorithm combining record, strength of schedule, and a bonus for conference championship and it produced this result (score in parentheses): Alabama (95.7%)Clemson (83.6%)Ohio State (80.8%)Washington (80.6%)Penn State (75.4%)Oklahoma (74.0%)Michigan (70.4%)W Michigan (68.0%)Wisconsin (62.3%)USC (60.6%) Looks fair enough, right? And it wouldn’t be a “secret formula” and there’d be no concern of coaches “gaming the system” (they’re just rewarded for winning). Wouldn’t this be a lot more fair? What am I missing?
